review.title: A Piece of My Mind: A Sentiment Analysis Approach for Online Dispute Detection
review.abstract: We investigate the novel task of online dispute detection and propose a sentiment analysis solution to the problem: we aim to identify the sequence of sentence-level sentiments expressed during a discussion and to use them as features in a classifier that predicts the DISPUTE/NON-DISPUTE label for the discussion as a whole. We evaluate dispute detection approaches on a newly created corpus of Wikipedia Talk page disputes and find that classifiers that rely on our sentiment tagging features outperform those that do not. The best model achieves a very promising F1 score of 0.78 and an accuracy of 0.80.

sections.heading: 2 Data Construction: A Dispute Corpus
sections.text: We construct the first Dispute Recognition Corpus to date; it consists of dispute and non-dispute discussions from Wikipedia Talk pages. Step 1: Get Talk Pages of Disputed Articles. Wikipedia articles are edited by different editors. If an article is observed to have disputes on its discussion page, editors can assign dispute tags to the article to mark it for attention. In this research, we are interested in talk pages whose corresponding articles are labeled with the following keywords: Dispute (POV). We use the 2013-03-04 Wikipedia data to dump and extract conversation pages for articles containing Dispute-SECTION, POV. The keywords indicate that an article is controversial, or the neutrality of the article is controversial (POV).

sections.heading: 3 Sentence-level Sentiment Prediction
sections.text: This section describes our sentence-level sentiment tagger, from which we construct characteristics for detecting disputes > Sentiment (Section 4). Consider a discussion consisting of sequential phrases; each turn consists of a sequence of phrases. Our model takes the sentences x = {x1, ·, xn} from a single turn as input and returns the corresponding sequence of sentiment markers y = {y1, ·, yn}, in which the sentences x = {NN, N, O, P, PP} are wrong. The terms in O represent very negative (NN), negative (N), positive (O), positive (P), and very positive (PP), or very positive characteristics. Given the fact that traditional conditional fields (CRFs) (Lafferty et al., 2001) ignore the ordinal relations between sentential markers, we choose isotonic Fs CRs (Maxi analysis, 2007 and Sententiality-level).

sections.heading: 4.1 Training A Sentiment Classifier
sections.text: We train the mood classifier using the authority and alignment PP in Wikipedia Discussions (AAWD) corpus (Bender et al., 2011) on a 5-point scale (i.e. NN, N, O, P, PP). AAWD consists of 221 English Wikipedia discussions with positive and negative alignment annotations. Annotators mark each sentence as either positive, negative or neutral, or label the complete turn. If a sentence has only one turn-level label, we assume that all sentences have the same label as the turn. We further transform the labels into the five sentiment labels. Annotations are treated as positive alignment by at least two annotators (PP). If a sentence is selected as positive only by an annotator, or the label as negative annotator, or the label as negative annotation system, it is positive (P). Very negative (NN) and negative (polotator) are predicted as positive in other ways (O).

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: A sentiment prediction model based on isotonic CRFs is proposed to issue sentiment labels at the sentence level. Experiments on our Dispute Corpus also show that classifiers trained with emotion-marking features outperform others who do not.
